text.p: These are the leading stories in Albania's main newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The paper publishes two different stories on the resignation of President Sali Berisha, one saying he will not resign until his defeated Democratic Party's congress in autumn, the other that he will resign on Monday.

- The Central Elections Commission is not declaring the final results of June 29 elections because its leftist coalition members want President Sali Berisha to declare in writing that he will resign shortly after he decrees the convening of parliament.
- Socialist Party leader Fatos Nano faces no legal hurdles to become prime minister, said the lawyer who defended him when he was convicted of embezzlement.
- Interim Prime Minister Bashkim Fino said he is playing soccer every afternoon to show President Berisha he has nothing to do and it is time to convene parliament.
- Democratic Alliance Party ministers will refuse to be sworn in by President Sali Berisha.

- Italian troops from an international protection force have gradually started leaving Albania. The Romanian contingent has left the southern town of Gjirokaster for the port of Durres to take a ferry home.
- The Interior Ministry has sent special troops to the southern town of Berat to restore law and order there.
- Foreign companies have invested $284 million in Albania from 1992 to 1996 but Albanian authorities now should provide more incentives to lure investors back.
- Former prime minister Aleksander Meksi denied that a cooperation accord with Italy had not been signed because Albania refused to provide transparency over pyramid schemes.
- The International Monetary Fund might send a team to Albania in August.
- Shpetim Nazarko, publisher of the Dita Informacion daily, will be the second candidate for president.
- Supervision by the European Union's D 21 department brought a boom in customs duties collection at Albania's Durres port last month.
